content:
“The accumulation of all powers, legislative, executive, and judiciary, in the same hands, whether of one, a few, or many, and whether hereditary, self-appointed, or elective, may justly be pronounced the very definition of tyranny.”

— James Madison, Federalist No. 47

——-

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, the President of the United States said:

“Usually, they say, ‘he’s a horrible dictator type person,’ I’m a dictator. But sometimes you need a dictator.”

The audience laughed.

But the Founders did not design the Constitution to survive only sincere men speaking carefully. They designed it to withstand ambition spoken casually, and to sound the alarm when jest and action begin to rhyme.

——-

The Pattern

Since September 2025, the United States military has conducted at least 26 strikes on boats in the Caribbean and Pacific, killing at least 95 people. None of the dead have been identified by the government. None received a trial. The legal basis is a classified memo from the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel. The list of designated terrorist organizations justifying the killings is secret.

Human Rights Watch has declared these strikes unlawful extrajudicial killings. The UN special rapporteur on extrajudicial executions has condemned them. The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has said the same.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio, asked about interdiction, said: “What will stop them is when you blow them up.”

On January 3, 2026, the United States launched a military assault on Venezuela. Fighter jets. Attack helicopters. Special forces. The operation bombed infrastructure across northern Venezuela, captured the sitting president in his home, and transported him to New York for trial.

At his press conference afterward, the President said the United States would “run the country” until a transition could be arranged. He expressed openness to a prolonged occupation, noting it would cost America nothing because Venezuela’s oil would pay for it.

Chatham House, the Atlantic Council, and legal scholars across the political spectrum have called the operation a clear violation of the UN Charter. There was no congressional authorization. There was no Security Council mandate. There was no imminent armed attack requiring self-defense.

The administration called it a law enforcement action.

Within days, the President turned his attention to Greenland. He said the United States “needs” the territory. He refused to rule out military force. He said he does not “need international law.” He threatened tariffs against Denmark and seven other European nations unless they support the takeover.

Denmark is a NATO ally. Greenland is NATO territory.

The Danish Prime Minister warned that a US attack on Greenland would mean “everything stops, including our NATO.” Denmark and allied nations have now deployed troops to the island. The President’s deputy chief of staff posted an image of Greenland draped in an American flag with a single word: “SOON.”

And throughout this period, the President and his family have accumulated billions of dollars through cryptocurrency ventures entangled with foreign governments. A House Judiciary Committee report documented crypto holdings worth as much as $11.6 billion and income exceeding $800 million in the first half of 2025 alone. A $2 billion transaction routed through a Trump family stablecoin involved a firm controlled by the UAE’s national security adviser. Two weeks later, that same UAE entity gained access to advanced American AI chips.

The administration has dismantled the Justice Department’s cryptocurrency enforcement team. It has dropped investigations into firms that donated to the President or invested in his companies. It has pardoned individuals convicted of crypto-related crimes who provided financial support to his ventures.

——-

The Doctrine, Applied

On January 7, 2026, an ICE agent shot and killed Renee Nicole Good in Minneapolis. She was 37 years old, seated in her car.

The Department of Homeland Security called her a rioter. Video of the incident tells a different story. Minnesota officials sought to investigate. The federal government blocked them from the scene and refused to share evidence.

Two days later, Vice President Vance stood at the White House podium and announced the doctrine:

“The precedent here is very simple. You have a federal law enforcement official engaging in federal law enforcement action, that’s a federal issue. That guy is protected by absolute immunity. He was doing his job.”

Constitutional scholars immediately rejected the claim. Absolute immunity does not exist for federal law enforcement officers. States have prosecuted federal agents before. The law requires that force be reasonable and necessary.

But the administration did not argue that the shooting was reasonable. It argued that reasonableness is not a question anyone may ask.

A Wall Street Journal investigation found that since July, ICE agents have fired into civilians’ vehicles at least 13 times, twice fatally.

Six federal prosecutors in Minnesota resigned.

——-

What the Founders Feared

The Founders did not define tyranny as a title claimed or a crown worn.

Madison defined it as the accumulation of powers in the same hands. Hamilton warned that executive energy, unbound by law, becomes arbitrary. Washington described despotism arriving not with armies but through “the spirit of encroachment” that consolidates power gradually, until resistance forgets how to resist.

They built a system of separated powers precisely because they understood that ambition does not announce itself. It probes. It tests. It finds the boundaries that bend before it finds the ones that break.

A president who orders executions without trial has accumulated judicial power. A president who launches invasions without congressional authorization has accumulated legislative power. A president who threatens allies with military force to acquire territory has abandoned the framework of law entirely. A president who enriches himself through foreign transactions while in office has created the very dependency the Founders feared most. An administration that declares its agents beyond prosecution has placed enforcement itself outside the law.

——-

The Question Before Us

When the President said “sometimes you need a dictator,” he was not revealing a secret. He was describing what he has already done.

The extrajudicial killings are not hypothetical. The invasion is not threatened. The immunity claims are not abstract. The wealth is not speculative. The pattern is documented, exposed to public view, and defended by officials who no longer bother to disguise it as anything other than what it is.

The Founders never asked citizens to guess motive. They asked them to guard structure.

They knew that power announces itself first as jest, then as necessity, then as policy, and only finally as command. By the time the command is given, the audience has already been trained to applaud.

The question is not whether the President was joking in Davos. The question is whether the American republic still recognizes the difference between a joke and a confession.

That is how republics end. Not with a dictator who seizes power. But with a public that watches him describe it, and laughs.

——-
